ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: almost none
2hrs
about 2 hours in total. This class only met once
I spent about 90 minutes preparing for the seminar.
This year we only had one session! A few hours to do the readings and a few more to do the online trainings, but that's it.
2 hours that single week to complete the irb hipaa material
1 hour
great
less than one
3 hours total - doing 3 on-line Yale "seminars" on research topics; and reading some of the preparatory information
N/A
3 hours
2 hours
5 hours that particular week.
1 meeting for entire term2 hours of work
NA
5+ once doing the readings and the trainings
Only spent about 2-3 hours total this semester for HIPAA training and reading over the case for the discussion portion of the seminar.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I think that we need more of this type of training. More opportunities to discuss these issues and to anticipate challenges and learn from other students' experiences.
It was fine...truncated and in many ways felt unprepared
good
This class is a waste of time for those who have research or clinical experience. It should not be mandatory to AP students.
I didn't really see the point of this.
We only had one day of the seminar that was supposed to happen twice, but I still didn't find it very helpful. We talk about ethics in almost every class anyway.
Interesting. Generated a lot of conversation and provided new insight into ethics. I am considering this as a career option.
Very interesting and essential to research/work in the field of public health.
This seminar was cut from 2 days to 1 day. I didn't get much out of it. There was barely any discussion in the smaller group I attended after the main lecture.
This was a helpful refresher about the importance and considerations of ethics and professionalism.
Not sure what I got out of this other than a free pizza lunch.
needs to highlight the importance of HIC/HIPAA issues in research better
Really boring.
I think it's an important topic, and a good introduction to ethics for students.

I honestly did not get a lot out of this course. The first speaker posed some interesting normative thought questions about ethics. We also had an interesting discussion regarding gun violence in the breakout session. It seems like the course could have been better catered towards the kind of ethical dilemmas we might face in a career in public health: for folks in epi - how to properly deal with study participants; for people in policy/management - how to deal with high cost patients, improve access at the expense of profitability, etc...perhaps if the section was split into individuals in their respective divisions and have industry leaders talk about some ethical dilemmas they have faced, and how to go about dealing with them. This would be much more practical and easier make for easier participation (smaller groups).
Discussion is more helpful

This was a very rudimentary course and I feel I should have been able to opt out after having had two courses in bioethics, which taught me much more than this could. Ethics is an extremely important topic, but you need to have more interesting and complicated conversations about it fore it to actually influence people's practice and not just be a nominal exercise.
it was good, a little hard to sit through due to length and material but the weather was harsh on us all =)

It was a pretty general course. I did like the fact that our TA was a non-public health student who had a different perspective on ethics - our TA was a medical student. I would suggest to continue recruiting individuals outside of YSPH to incorporate variety.

The first half of the class was too rushed and dense with information that was not particularly relevant to our other classes. The topic for the second half of the class (gun violence as a public health issue) did not lend itself to discussion. The discussion groups were also too large.
I did not gain anything from this seminar. The idea of an ethics seminar for public health practitioners is good in theory, but it still has lots of room for improvement.
Useful and practical/.
great

I think we need to do a longer seminar. One day was not enough on this content and ethics is a critical element of being a public health professional. Not just research ethics, but overall ethical considerations in decision-making is not something we get training on. It's important.
somewhat interesting, mostly boring, but a useful course to take. I did not find the discussion to be useful at all. It turned into a debate about guns, nothing to do with ethics.

This is very important, interesting material. However, to shove this material into 2 afternoons (and one in our case due to the blizzard) really diminished its relevance. Having us take the on-line Yale courses, could be done in the week prior to starting school and not during school as this was just an added burden with all the other work we have. And, this material really deserves a longer discussion. Either make it a real course, for credit - or don't even try to do it, as it just didn't do it justice to have it as a small add-on thing. As it was, this important, interesting material, was just a silly, nuisance the way it was done.However, we have too much other work to make this into a bigger, add-on course. Can you start school 1 week earlier and focus on the "ethics" on one week prior to other work starting?
Labs required too much work. They assumed the students had a higher level of SAS experience than was the norm.
This was a one time seminar. I think it would be helpful to have a course on bioethics instead.
good
Break-out discussion sections were the most useful, although scenarios used for practice could have been improved.
Was useful in helping us understand some of the issues associated with public health research. It was unfortunate that our time was limited in these courses due to the storm.
great discussion session talking about topics in ethics
Great
Informative

I think it's a necessary component of the public health curriculum and this seems as reasonable format as any to teach ethics. I liked the breakout sessions!I think it may have been better if we had been able to have both sessions- it seems like we didn't quite get enough of the material in just one.
good
It felt like a formality or an item on a todo list. I did not really enhance my understanding of research ethics.
having a bigger class for labs would be really helpful !
We did not get to do the full series because of the weather so it was not as in depth as it could have been but that was probably because of the shorten time.
Strength- Knowledge of the instructors about the topicWeakness- We had just one session, so did not help
I like the fact that this course is very interactive and is organized like a discussion.Areas to improve might be adding more topics for case studies.
I thought the setup was great before the snow storm forced a consolidation of the classes.

This year's structure was different given there was only one session. The course was far too didactic. I would have much preferred to have the case-based discussion broken up into two parts with a lecture in between -- that way, initial thoughts would be cultivated among student groups, then we'd all learn about principles of research and justice ethics, and finally we'd return to our case-based discussions with new tools to discuss and reflect on the topic.
Fantastic
This course was a great introduction to research ethics. It would have been great to have two different sessions instead of lumping both sessions into one.
Brought up interesting points that are useful for research/internship work

Strengths: This is an important topic that merits a special seminar, and I thought the case study on gun control that was discussed during the breakout session provided a good way for the other students and I to hash out some of the ethical issues surrounding a topic. I also found Dr. Khoshnood's talk on some of the ethical issues he has encountered in conducting his own work to be very eye-opening. Weaknesses/Possible Improvements: While I thought it was good to have some background on research ethics, I thought the lecture portion of the seminar was a bit long. I know the seminar was shortened overall due to the storm, but I thought the time that was available would have been better spent with a brief lecture on research ethics and more discussion on the case studies. I also really enjoyed Dr. Khoshnood's talk on ethical issues he has encountered in his own work and would have enjoyed hearing from more YSPH professors!!
NA
Necessary yet poorly taught because of how rushed it had to be (not the instructors fault)
It was compressed into one day.

Great that you have this seminar. I know it usually takes 2 sessions to complete, but I believe there should be more sessions--4 to 6.I did not understand the purposes of the case studies. We had not learned much about ethics in that one hour lecture so our discussions were not that solid. I think more time should have been devoted to listening to the two instructors.
maybe to have more organized discussions led by experienced TAs would make it better
I think the seminar would have been more helpful if it was offered in the two sessions, as originally planned. Enjoyed the case discussion.

Unfortunately because of a snow storm we were short-changed and given only one seminar. All of the information was condensed into one meeting and I really believe we were cheated out of a really important class. Ethics should not be treated as a two-day seminar. I suggest in the future the class be a month-long seminar. Other than those points, I do not think I can provide any further feedback that can be viewed as constructive except that administrators or the seminar professors be more selective in the selection of student discussion leaders. Please see my comments under TA.
Informative and helpful.

I am not the best judge of this course since I arrived late and left early due to scheduling conflicts. I think the content of this course is great and useful to many MPH students. The snow days interrupted the logistics of this course.

The discussion was a waste of time - there were no clear guidelines and the discussion degenerated into people's personal opinions on gun-control, not about the ethics of engaging in the gun control debate
A very quick overview
It was fine the way it is

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Bruce Jennings  His speech was great.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  good
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very poorly done.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very intelligent with lots of information.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Great lecture!
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I enjoyed Professor Jennings' presentation.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Nice, but not so engaging.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I really enjoyed Dr. Jennings and his portion of the seminar. It was quite informative.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Fine

Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Outstanding. My friends and I left the class wondering when we could take more of Prof. Jennings courses. I even took an Ethics course last semester and found his comments profound and adding to my knowledge.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Helpful and kind.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  great
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Clearly very knowledgeable
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  His lecture could use some freshening up. It was a little boring.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good lecture. But, strange to shove such important, interesting information into a quick, on-timelecture.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  good
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Lecture on justice and ethics was a necessary primer for the course, but would have appreciated more focus on public health topics rather than ethical truisms.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I really enjoyed his talk and hearing his perspective.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good lecturer- it may have been nice to have a bit more of an engaging format.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  good
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I didn't hear the teacher because I was seated on the floor behind the room.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Lecture could have been made more interesting.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  He is good.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very good.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Strengths -- clearly very well-versed on the subject matterWeaknesses -- lecture was very didactic and boring, visually engaging handouts may have been helpful
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Great
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I really appreciated Dr. Jennings teachings on the fundamental principles of ethics.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I found the brief background on ethics to be interesting but would have preferred if it drew upon a greater number of public health examples.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  NA
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Lecture was long and not very engaging.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Great speaker. Would have appreciated learning more from him.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  maybe to bring in more real life examples would make the presentation more interesting
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Great.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Great!
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good discussion
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Excellent - you can tell that he cares deeply about students and these issues.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  good
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great job.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Very engaging.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great lecture, wish the class was longer.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I loved hearing about Dr. Khoshnood's field experiences. I thought they served as excellent case studies, which helped widen my perspective and awareness of ethical issues that may/will come up during public health/scientific research.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I enjoyed Professor Khoshnood's presentation.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I really enjoyed Dr. Khoshnood and his portion of the seminar.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Very good actually if you listened to him, it was hard to sit for that long with this type of subject but he made some good points!
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Genuinely cares.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Helpful and kind.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  great
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh's great!
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Absolutely great, he was able to keep me interested in a topic that is kind of boring by using personal examples to illustrate his points. I was actually entertained.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Good lecture. But, strange to shove such important, interesting information into a quick, on-time lecture.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  good

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Very interesting. Enjoyed his more applied approach, although he stated that learning to communicate with policy makers was important as sometimes the "science doesn't speak for itself"; would have preferred to hear more on this subject.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I also really enjoyed this talk, though unfortunately we had little time due to the snow storm.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Engaging professor- very interesting examples.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  good
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I didn't hear the teacher because I was seated on the floor behind the room.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Made the session really interesting with discussion of real cases
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is great. Very easy going and has clear structure.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great, enthusiastic, thought provoking.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Strengths -- lecture was a bit more interesting/engaging than counterpart'sWeaknesses -- should start lecture off by asking how many students have previously participated in the IRB process and use that response to drive conversation more so than didactic lecturing
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I really enjoyed Dr. Kaveh's real-life examples of research ethics cases.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I found Dr. Khoshnood's talk on some of the ethical issues he has encountered in conducting his own work to be very eye-opening. This was my favorite and the most memorable part of the seminar for me. it made me really appreciate the complexity of the issue.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  NA
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Did a great job relating to real world issues and getting the student's attention
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Same as above.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  nice presentation
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is a very kind, warm, and passionate instructor. One can tell that he likes his job and cares for students. I think that he should continue his work in the area of research ethics because it is needed in the fields of public health and medicine.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Great!
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Good lecture

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: It is what you make of it.

It's about ethics, but just not really taught well at all..it was more of a blip of course rather than something that will really stick in the minds of students..which is sad because this is a pretty important topic.
good
No
I wouldn't recommend this course. I think there's a lot of overlap from what we discuss in other classes.
Yes, it was a nice seminar.
Essential to everyone's work in the field. The break out session was an effective way to practice skills gained in the lecture portion of the course. Thank you!
Very easy to complete, seemed like a waste of time
This course provides a helpful refresher on professional ethics and research ethics, which are important for anyone who is pursuing a career in public health.
Several hour seminar on general ethics, not research ethics.
It was really boring. I didn't get anything out of it. The only thing that was useful was getting the HIPAA training certification.
Good introduction to ethical dilemmas that students might face, and would recommend.

I would not recommend this course to a fellow student in its present state. I would say that there are interesting broad discussions about ethics, but none about the sort of practical ethical decisions you might deal with in your public health practice.

very importantAlso there is something wrong with this survey there is no drop down menu for TA and the system won't submit unless we use a drop down menu. So I "declined to answer" but the response is here, belowTA: Jasmine: very great as always, she is a very good asset to her students and was good in leading a discussion between everyone and not just a few.
Great class!
Essential to take.
useful
Overview of ethical issues one could face while doing research in the field.

Important, interesting information - but shoved into a very short, quick, summary discussion, that diminished its use and made it a silly, nuisance.However, we have too much other work to make this into a bigger, add-on course. Can you start school 1 week/or a few days earlier and focus on the "ethics" in one week prior to other work starting?
good
Short session on justice and ethics with break-out sessions that cover ethical problems you may encounter during your summer internship.
Great oversight
Brief summary of research ethics, with a few select case studies
The content needs to be more engaging.
Research ethics is important and so one session is not good enough
A good one to take during your MPH studies.
Valuable course. Glad it is part of the curriculum.
Not bad.One meeting the whole term. Effort cut short because of snow day in February.Things you already know. Presented in a fun way so that's good.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it got me thinking about research in a way I hadn't before. It was a great introduction to bioethics.

Although I feel this course needs a lot of changes, I would recommend it to another student because it is really important for public health students to understand the ethical considerations involved in undertaking research projects.
silly
Overview of ethical issues in Public Health
Do the readings and take the trainings seriously. Having a basic ethical knowledge is important for public health professionals.
an essential course for public health students. would recommend it.
I personally feel like I had a bad experience but I would recommend this to another student only because the topic of ethics is so crucial for our education as future public health leaders.
Informative and helpful.
It is a great course and I would recommend it to other students. Hopefully, the logistics will work out better next year.
Required seminar, good discussion.
It's fine
